feed.title: NewsTracker: cyclone vanuatu
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: IOC president Bach visits cyclone-hit facilities on Vanuatu
entry.summary: Bach says "what surprises me the most is the confidence and optimism level Vanuatu people have, and that is the true Olympic spirit ... we hope that our contribution will give hope to the whole population."

entry.title: Almost half Vanuatu people lack clean water, month after cyclone: UNICEF
entry.summary: "There is water but quality is not that good because of the contamination," Ketsamay Rajphangthong, chief of UNICEF Vanuatu field office, told the Thomson Reuters Foundation in a phone interview from Vanuatu.

entry.title: UN appeals for $20 million for Vanuatu cyclone victims
entry.summary:
UNITED NATIONS (AP) - The United Nations is appealing for nearly $20 million for victims of Cyclone Pam which tore through the South Pacific island nation of Vanuatu last month.

A U.N. appeal for about $30 million was launched on March 24 to cover the needs of 166,000 cyclone-affected people for three months but Dujarric said that to date donors have given only $10.7 million, just 36 per cent.

entry.title: U.N. targets shelter, water in $29.9 million appeal for cyclone-hit Vanuatu
Half of Vanuatu's population affected by Cyclone Pam: UN
entry.summary:
More than half of the South Pacific island nation Vanuatu's population has been affected by Cyclone Pam, the UN said Saturday as the death toll rose to 16.

"Around 166,000 people, more than half of Vanuatu's population, have been affected by Tropical Cyclone Pam on 22 islands," the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) said in a situation report.

entry.title: 5 Things to Know About Vanuatu's Devastating Cyclone
entry.summary: This aerial view of a small island in Vanuatu's north shows the extent to which the island has been denuded by Cyclone Pam, on Friday, March 20, 2015.

entry.title: 5 things to know about Vanuatu's devastating cyclone
entry.summary: Cyclone Pam transformed much of Vanuatu from a tropical green to a dirty brown overnight, as coconut trees were stripped of their foliage and snapped like matchsticks and even some mighty banyan trees were toppled.

entry.title: 5 things to know about Vanuatu's devastating cyclone
entry.summary: Aid agencies, many of which were active in Vanuatu before the cyclone, have arrived in sometimes overwhelming numbers.

entry.title: A week after Vanuatu cyclone, some homeless still await help
Vanuatu provides lessons in cyclone survival [Photos]
Cyclone Pam rips through Vanuatu's Manua school
entry.summary: As Cyclone Pam ripped at the roof of Manua School, a group of men, women and children pulled desperately on electrical cable keeping them from harm.

entry.title: Vanuatu after Cyclone Pam: Risk of hunger and disease rises
entry.summary: A young boy looks at the debris of his home, badly damaged by Cyclone Pam on the Vanuatu island of Tanna on March 18.

entry.title: Cyclone Pam: At least eight Australians missing in Vanuatu
entry.summary:
Zoe Marshall was in Vanuatu when cyclone Pam devastated the region.

Eight Australians are among 19 volunteer teachers missing in Vanuatu, five days after Cyclone Pam tore through the Pacific nation.

entry.title: Fears of food, water shortages persist as relief groups rush aid to Vanuatu
entry.summary: Baldwin Lonsdale, Vanuatu's president, returned to his country on Tuesday night from Japan, where had been attending a UN disaster conference when the cyclone struck.

entry.title: Food concerns mount in Vanuatu after cyclone Pam
Relief teams reach Vanuatu's cyclone-hit outer islands
entry.summary: In this March 15, 2015 photo provided by UNICEF Pacific, a man works to recover from Cyclone Pam in Mele village, on the outskirts of the capital Port Vila, Vanuatu.

entry.title: Relief teams reach Vanuatu's cyclone-hit outer islands
entry.summary: In this Monday, March 16, 2015 photo, clothes are seen laid out to dry as Adrian Banga surveys his destroyed house in Vanuatu's capital Port Vila.

entry.title: Relief teams reach Vanuatu's cyclone-hit outer islands
entry.summary: Damage to houses in Port Vila, Vanuatu is seen from the air in the aftermath of Cyclone Pam Monday, March 16, 2015.

entry.title: Rescue teams reach cyclone stricken Vanuatu islands, official toll lowered
Cyclone Pam: Is it time for a category-6 cyclone rating?
entry.summary: The unusual strength of Cyclone Pam, which devastated Vanuatu over the weekend, may stir debate about the need for a category-6 rating for storms to reflect their increasing severity.

entry.title: AP Interview: Vanuatu President Rues Cyclone Devastation
entry.summary: Baldwin Lonsdale, president of Vanuatu, the Pacific island nation devastated by a powerful tropical storm last week, was attending a disaster conference in the Japanese city of Sendai when the cyclone struck.

entry.title: Cyclone-ravaged Vanuatu struggles to determine scale of damage, deaths as aid starts flowing
entry.summary: "There are over 80 islands that make up Vanuatu and on a good, sunny day outside of cyclone season it's difficult to get to many of them," said Collett van Rooyen of Oxfam.

entry.title: Vanuatu Struggles to Account for Cyclone Damage
entry.summary: Officials in Vanuatu had still not made contact with outlying islands and were struggling to determine the scale of devastation from the cyclone, which tore through early Saturday, packing winds of 270 kilometers (168 miles) per hour.

entry.title: Vanuatu president speaks of devastation from Cyclone Pam
Vanuatu president speaks of devastation from Cyclone Pam
entry.summary: A: "This is a very devastating cyclone in Vanuatu. I term it as a monster, a monster. It's a setback for the government and for the people of Vanuatu. After all the development that has taken place, all this development has been wiped out. So it means we will have to start anew again."

entry.title: Cyclone Pam: Australia gives Vanuatu $5 million in aid
Cyclone Pam: Vanuatu death toll rises as Australia pledges $5m in aid ? as it happened
entry.summary: The first shipments of aid headed for Vanuatu on Sunday as authorities declared a state of emergency and global relief agencies geared up after a powerful cyclone tore through the vulnerable Pacific island nation.

entry.title: Cyclone Pam: 'It was like a velociraptor', as Australians survive Vanuatu cyclone
entry.summary: While the worst of the storm lasted for just twelve hours, the cyclone has left a lasting mark on the people and infrastructure of Vanuatu, Mr Ang told Fairfax Media while he queued for petrol on the Kumul Highway.

entry.title: Cyclone Pam death toll to 'increase significantly' in Vanuatu
entry.summary:
Residents look through the remains of a small shelter in Port Vila, the capital city of Vanuatu.

A Nasa satellite image of cyclone Pam as the eye of the storm passes just east of Vanuatu.

entry.title: Vanuatu appeals for aid after cyclone 'calamity'
entry.summary: Fiji Weather Service meteorologist Neville Koop said the cyclone was weakening as it slowly moved away from Vanuatu, and would pass between Fiji and New Caledonia before brushing the North Island of New Zealand on Monday.

entry.title: Aid workers say 8 people confirmed dead after cyclone hits Vanuatu in South Pacific
News24.com | Britain donates ?2m to cyclone-struck Vanuatu
entry.summary: Residents look through storm damage caused by Cyclone Pam, in the Vanuatu capital of Port Vila.

entry.title: Cyclone Pam: Dozens feared dead in Vanuatu
Cyclone Pam leaves trail of destruction in Pacific's Vanuatu
entry.summary: In this photo provided by non-governmental organization 350.org, debris is scattered over a building in Port Vila, Vanuatu, Saturday, March 14, 2015, in the aftermath of Cyclone Pam.

entry.title: Cyclone Pam leaves trail of destruction in Pacific's Vanuatu
entry.summary: The president of Vanuatu, Baldwin Lonsdale, who was attending the conference, told participants: "I do not really know what impact the cyclone has had on Vanuatu."

entry.title: Cyclone Pam leaves swath of destruction in Pacific's Vanuatu
entry.summary: WELLINGTON, New Zealand -- Winds from an extremely powerful cyclone that blew through the Pacific's Vanuatu archipelago were beginning to subside Saturday, revealing widespread destruction and unconfirmed reports of dozens of deaths.

entry.title: Cyclone Pam Leaves Trail of Destruction in Pacific's Vanuatu
entry.summary:
A westward change of course put populated areas directly in the path of Cyclone Pam's 270 kilometer (168 mile) -per-hour winds.

The U.N. Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs said there were unconfirmed reports of deaths in Vanuatu's northeastern islands after Cyclone Pam moved off its expected track.

entry.title: Cyclone Pam hits small Pacific nation of Vanuatu
